<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
```
</target_code>

})

{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}

}

suspicious_frags: metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",		  ret);
explanation: The macro definition uses a GCC-style statement expression '({ ... })' and the '##__VA_ARGS__' token-pasting to swallow a comma — both are compiler extensions in common compilers and must be investigated under MISRA C Rule 1.2. The listed metal_log call sites expand to that macro and therefore should be inspected as well. Other fragments in the provided code (pthread_join, close, write, use of __func__, static variables, uint64_t, bool, metal_mutex_deinit, function definitions, etc.) are standard C or library/API calls and do not by themselves constitute use of a language compiler extension, so they do not require investigation for Rule 1.2.
